result.execSummary:
The defendant GABRIEL GARRETT CHAPIN was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse Assessments], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
If revoked, Defendant entitled to 8 days of jail credit.
Concurrent with: Count 2 and any previously imposed sentence.

miscConds.notes: Outstanding financial obligations are to be paid directly to the Winnebago County Clerk of Courts within 60 days. Payment plans are available in the Clerk of Courts office. Do NOT pay Probation Agent. Debts older than 90 days will be processed for civil judgment and sent to the Department of Revenue for collection including tax intercept. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Complete compas assessment,  counseling, evaluations, programs and assessments as appropriate and followup. 

Follow through with any mental health treatment and follow all Chapter 51 orders.   Take all prescribed medications. 

Pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections and follow rules of supervision. 

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample.  Contact Court Security at 920-236-4906 to schedule an appointment.  The appointment location is:  Room 15 on the lower level of the Courthouse, 415 Jackson Street Oshkosh WI.  Defendant shall provide proof of identification along with the court minutes stating a DNA sample is required.  Failure to comply with this order may result in either a finding of contempt of court or a criminal charge of Failure to Provide a DNA Sample pursuant to Wis. Stats., 946.52.
